The initial cost of' an instructional, television system is substantial0
However, such information ..as is presently available clearly indicates that
when the number of students reached exceeds: approximately 250, the per pupil
costs arc less than for traditional instructiono If there is added to the
picture the value of television in teacher training, and improvement, and the
probability of reduced long term goals for the number of teachers and class¬
rooms, televised education becomes a sound economical investment for the
next quarter of a century0
Thus, through educational television wherever it is feasible, a
massive educational job can be undertaken at a completely justifiable price0
In many situations an equally massive job cannot be undertaken in the near
future through traditional means at any price•
Because the educational job to be accomplished in the emerging
countries is so vast, the resources with which to attack the job are so meager,
and the time in which substantial progress must be made is so short, every
feasible means for increasing the efficiency of the educational process must
be utilizedo Beyond a reasonable doubt, television has the capacity to make
a major contribution in this regard0
It is time that ICA assume a posture that will permit the Agency
to appraise situations realistically and enable it to implement television
projects which give promise of significantly augmenting educational programs
for both in-school and out-of-school learners•
Policy Recommendations
One of the vitally important, possibly the most important, aspect
of television development that should become a concern of ICA is the future
availability of excellent, substantive program materials and a body of
techniques and know-how for producing, adapting, and utilizing these materials»
While extensive programs of research and development aimed at these problems
within the context of United States education are underway, there is no major
program geared to accomplishing the same job on a world wide basiso As tele¬
vision becomes available on a wider scale, there will be an increasing demand
for guidance and assistance in the procurement and preparation of educational
program materials0 If ICA is to have meaningful help to provide, it is not
too soon to attack the complex problems involvede
ICA should undertake an extensive research and development program
in the communications media field0 Included in such a project would be pro¬
vision for ■the acquisition ,anc|;; experimental!-production- qf '■ educatprogram
materials for television, the development of methods and techniques of pro¬
ducing such materials and adapting them for use in different cultures,
experimentation in the utilization of television materials in differing
situations, and the dissemination of information on all of these and related
problemso It is not contemplated that ICA would get into the business of
supplying programs for regular use0 On the contrary, the materials collected
would serve as prototypes to the end that ICA could provide guidance in assisting
host countries to acquire or produce their own materials0
